content.description:
This along with the Gift probably constitute the two most classic sport routes at the Gallery.  This one is exceedingly popular, so best to be patient if you plan on giving this one multiple tries.   

  Fun pumpy climbing follows the crack system, though no actual crack climbing is required.  As with the other routes at the Gallery, this one is probably a bit soft compared to similarly graded climbs at, say, Rifle.  Classic and awesome climbing, nonetheless.
content.protection: 6 bolts to the anchor on the right side of the crack

content.description: Climb the first two bolts of The Glitch then head upwards on good holds separated by big moves. Make a span to a juggy side-pull then prepare for some small, slopey crimps as you pull over onto the slab.
content.protection: Bolts, carabiners at the chains
content.location: Shares the same start as The Glitch

content.protection: The draws are there, except for the first one.
content.location: The route on the right of The Gift. The Gift is the climb with the longest queue...lower from top anchors.

content.description:
This climb starts at the bottom of the obvious right leaning crack to the left of Sport Climbing is Neither. Pitch one is approx. 100 feet. Belay to the far left on a platform. Protect the horizontal crack with hand-sized gear. Pitch two starts right along the face, then up and left up the obvious crack. Belay at the tripod pedestal rock using slings or cordalette. Bring slings to leave and rap rings or walk off down the gulley behind the climb to the right. Bring approach shoes! We did not rap off, so we don't know all the details. 

  Also, no idea if this is an actual first ascent... The name is obvious, so if it has been climbed, I bet it's called this already.  If anyone knows of a previous FA party, let us know!
content.protection: Finger to hand size cams, standard nut rack.   Placements are not necessarily straightforward... You may consider the second pitch to be more of a scramble...
content.location: Left of Sport Climbing is Neither.

content.description:
The route name is a tribute to Mr. Denny Goode who first took me to The Gallery some 17 years ago and has been a consistently positive and encouraging member of the local climbing community for many years.  A great climber and an all around good dude! 

  Another warm-up at The Gallery.  Feels a bit easier than the 5.8 to the right.
content.protection:
5 Stainless Bolts to Double Mussy Anchor 

This route was bolted solely for the purpose of allowing for the first ascent, and the first ascent information is posted here solely to document the history of the first ascent. No person should read this posting with the assumption that this route or the fixed gear left behind is safe in any way or otherwise appropriate to allow for safe subsequent ascents. Climbing is dangerous and should only be done with the appropriate training and risk management practices that include providing for the climber's own safety. Attempting to climb this route as described above or by any other means or methods could result in injury or death.
content.location: 10 feet left of Sport Climbing is Neither

climbs.name: Social Disorder
climbs.fa: Scott Carson, Steve Bullock & Jonathan Knight, 1991

content.description: Pulling out of the pod and continuing up from there is pretty tough.  Requires some delicate footwork and long reaches.
content.protection: 5 bolts
content.location: Starts out of the right side of a pod, second route to the left of Yaak Crack

content.description:
This is the shortest and farthest left route at the Gallery that looks easy.  It's not even overhanging! 

  One strategy is to start with this route and keep moving right, see how far you can get!  I didn't get too far ...
content.protection: Three bolts to anchor

content.description: just a longer more sustained version of the other climbs there. not too well travelled , only do multiple goes if the gallery is empty.
content.protection: QD's are in place
content.location: Start up The Gift (3 bolts) then traverse out right, and finish with the crux moves of Nothing shocking.

content.description: This route lies right of "Pump First, Pay Later" and begins at a short, left-facing flake.
content.protection: Four bolts to a bolted anchor

climbs.name: Range of Motion
climbs.fa: Todd Swain, Dick Peterson, Peggy Buckey, 1990

content.description: This is the far left route at the Gallery- about 50' or so feet left of Sport Climbing is Neither. It's pretty much as hard as it looks- a tricky crux off the ground leads to steep climbing through a bulge and then to anchors.
content.protection: 5 bolts

content.description: The next route right of "Gelatin Pooch".  It's starting to get steep now ...
content.protection: Four bolts to a 2 bolt anchor

content.description: This is a steep climb on horizontal crimps. It is excellent and much more sustained than The Gift or Where the Down Boys Go. The crux consists of a few radical pulls of ok crimps. If you don't manage to clip the last bolt 'cause you're pumped, and then fall, you go for the big dive...
content.protection: QD's are in place + Anchors at the top.
content.location: start as for the glitch, then straight up. the right most route except for the glitch

content.description: Starts between A Day in the Life and Yaak Crack, next to a small tree. A bouldery start leads to a very thin and very sustained overhung face. The holds get bigger and the wall steeper as you go. 5.12a if you start off the shelf behind.
content.protection: Bolts to Chain Anchors.

content.description: Located to the left of A Day in the Life, climb out of the left side of the pod on good holds keep moving left after clipping the bolt and then right eventually rejoining the Gridlock 11a to the left.
content.protection: 5 bolts shared anchor with Running Amuck and the Gridlock 11a

content.description: Between Running Amuck and Gridlock Direct, start from the ground and mantle up onto the ledge to clip the first bolt, head right on jugs to a long move in order to clip the 3rd bolt climb straight up to the anchors.
content.protection: 5 bolts shared anchor with Running Amuck and Gridlock Direct

climbs.name: The Glitz
climbs.fa: Equipped by Jeff Pedersen; FA: Don Welsh - 1990

content.description: This beautiful line traverses the overhang at the far end of the Gallery, a few climbs to the right of The Gift. Hand over hand movement along a fantastic rail leads to a dynamic move followed shortly thereafter by a ginormous hueco rest. Continue up to solid anchors on the same face
content.protection: 6 bolts, 2 anchors

content.description:
One of the best and most famous hard-12 sport climbs in North America.  It's been called 12c for years, but most of the current guidebooks now rate it 12d.  This is an awesome, steep, strenuous route, involving thuggish climbing to a delicate crux at the very end.   

  Much of the climbing in the lower section would probably clock in at about 12a/b.  The crux, involving a technical high step and reach to an elusive pebble, is not that hard in of itself, but the precision required for this move is usually hard to come by after the pumpy climbing below.  For those who project in this grade range, the key to the redpoint is to ruthlessly wire the lower section so that one can arrive at the crux fresh. 

  On a sunny winter day, one can enjoyably spend the afternoon watching numerous people cruising the lower section only to be spit off by the crux, again and again and again.
content.protection: Bolts.  There are usually in situ QDs in place, except for the first bolt

content.description: The next route right of "Buck's Muscle World".  You have now graduated to 4 bolt routes!
content.protection: Four bolts to a 2 bolt anchor

content.description: The next route right of "Sport Climbing is Neither", and rather similar in difficulty.
content.protection: Three bolts (homemade hangers) to a bolted anchor

content.description: This route has sustained crimps throughout, and is slightly overhanging. A very fun start leads to a great pump as you keep climbing. Near the end you have the option of some more small crimps or a dynamic dead point. Either way you finish, this route is solid for the grade and a very enjoyable climb.
content.protection: Several bolts to the chain anchors.
content.location: Begin by starting at the small tree/bush and climbing out the right side of the pod in the middle of the wall. Continue up to the anchors through a series of crimps.

content.description:
The Gallery is south facing and warm on cold days. The routes range from 5.8 to 5.13a/b. The Gift (5.12d) has been climbed in several climbing videos and is one of the 18 routes at the Gallery.  

  [Reprinted with permission from Jed Botsford, Climbing Ranger - RRCNCA]. 

  IMPORTANT: Waste bags are provided by the Las Vegas Climbers Liaison Council in order to reduce human waste issues at the crags and boulders.  Please feel free to take one, use as directed, and dispose of in any trash receptacle.  Please do not leave them lying around, and do not throw them in the toilets at the parking areas.  The project was funded primarily by the American Alpine Club's Cornerstone Conservation Grant, with additional funding from the Access Fund and Mountain Gear.  Please do your part to be a good steward of this amazing climbing area.
